choices.B: specifying the maximum number of concurrent sessions allowed for a user
choices.C: specifying the amount of private space a session can allocate in the shared pool of the SGA
choices.D: limiting the degree of parallelism of operations performed by a user or group of users
choices.E: specifying an idle time limit that applies to sessions that are idle and blocking other sessions
choices.A: limiting the CPU used per database call

discussion.content:
I also agree on answer D and E. However answer A is also true because resource manager detects a session using exceeding CPU consumption (runaway quries, doc:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/dbrm.htm#ADMIN-GUID). Answer B would apply to number of active sessions in a consumergroup before being queued, I believe.

questions.question_text: For which two requirements would you use the Database Resource Manager?

choices.B: The command succeeds only if all the PDBs have the users and temp tablespaces.
choices.A: The common user is created in the CDB and all the PDBs, and uses the users and temp tablespaces of the CDB to store schema objects.

choices.C: The command gives an error because the container=all clause is missing.

discussion.content:
B correct
When creating a common user, any tablespace, tablespace group or profile specified in the CREATE command must exist in every PDB. If none of these are specified, the default TABLESPACE, TEMPORARY TABLESPACE, and PROFILE for the PDB will be used.

discussion.content: note that you can only create encrypted tablespaces; you cannot modify existing tablespaces to encrypt them. So, when you need existing data in encrypted tablespaces, the best solution is to first create encrypted tablespaces and then move the objects from the unencrypted tablespaces to them.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about a common user?

choices.A: A common user connected to a pluggable database (PDB) can exercise privileges across other PDBs.
choices.D: A common user can have a local schema in a PDB.
choices.E: A common user always uses the global temporary tablespace that is defined at the CDB level as the default temporary tablespace.
choices.B: A common user with the create user privilege can create other common users, as well as local users.
choices.C: A common user can be granted only a common role.

discussion.content:
The answer is BD

A common user can create other common users and local users if the common user has the CREATE USER privileged.
